Award.AwardTitle: Mass Dependent Bias in the Local Universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Miller and his group will study the spatial distribution of galaxy clusters, paying specific attention to the bias of cluster-sized dark matter halos. Such a bias results from massive dark matter halos forming within the largest fluctuations in the primordial matter density field. This induces a correlation between the halo mass and the amplitude of the clustering itself. Observational constraints on bias are a prerequisite to high precision cosmology using galaxy clusters. The program will publish a sample of approximately 1000 clusters with measured masses and well characterized errors.

Broader impacts of the work include training of a graduate student, building tutorials for web-based astronomy tools which lead non-specialists through some of the greatest astronomical discoveries, allowing non-scientists to discover for themselves the fundamental laws of the Universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is well known that clusters of galaxies are more strongly clustered than the galaxies they contain. This effect is known as bias, and it means that clusters must have a non-uniform spatial distribution even before they ``condense'' into the easily identified objects we see today. In this project, we constrained the cluster-scale bias and compared our results to predictions from theory and simulations and other observed measurements. Observational constraints on bias are a prerequisite to high precision cosmology with galaxy clusters.


Intellectual Merit: This project addresses fundamental questions about the growth of structure. Our current cosmological paradigm of LambdaCDM makes clear and observable predictions about how galaxy clusters trace the peaks in the underlying matter density field. This project highlights that carefully chosen datasets and algorithms can produce the needed precision to delineate between current collapse models for clusters. This project is grounded by using a single high quality observed dataset and by incorporqting an end-to-end simultaneous analysis using modern semi-analytic galaxy catalogs that closely resemble the observed low redshift universe. This project produced algorithms and data products that can be used for pressing challenges in other areas, like determining galaxy masses and understanding how galaxy properties might depend on their environments.

The three goals for this project were to: 1) collect new spectroscopy of galaxies in SDSS-C4 galaxy clusters in order to create complete samples and fix SDSS fiber collision issues; (2 Measure the escape velocity (caustic) masses of SDSS-C4 galaxy clusters; 3) Measure the mass dependent bias function using the SDSS-C4 cluster abundance and/or power spectrum.

Using the MDM/OSMOS and Magellan/IMACS multi-object spectrographs, we filled-in the missing data from the SDSS spectroscopy for the SDSS-C4 cluster sample. This effort required: Galaxy targets and masks to observe clusters which would have their caustic masses most improved with the additional spectra;  Reduction to wavelength calibrated 1D spectra of the IMACS spectra using COSMOS; Development of calibration software and then reduction to wavelength calibrated 1D spectra of the MDM spectra; Development of redshift determination software and then redshift estimation.

Using these new data as well as archival data, we built a new SDSS-C4 DR12 cluster catalog. We developed the theory and algorithms to self-calibrate the caustic masses using stacking to remove statistical bias and shape bias. We tested the algorithm on a mock C4 cluster sample with realistic sample selection algorithm, which required the SDSS-C4 algorithm to be run on the Henriques et al. (2011) light-cone mock galaxy sample. We showed that the self-calibration works in the mock data and in the real SDSS-C4 DR12 data using the mass richness relation. This work required additional development of software to measure scaling laws with correlated observational scatter in 2 dimensions and incorporate and LambdaCDM mass function dependent likelihood for the masses.

 

This project also developed new educational material which addresses the following questions: Can you prove that the Earth is not at the center of the Solar System? How can I discover Kepler's Laws for myself? How do I measure the real distances to planets?  How do I measure the mass of a planet? Did an eclipse really darken the Moai of Easter Island? These tutorials utilize the World Wide Telescope and Google Sky.
